prop.head.headtext: Remedies for Breach of Confidential Business Information
Remedy for Solicitor's Breach of Law of Conflicts

para.paratext: In Wallace v. Canadian Pacific Railway[1] the Supreme Court of Canada concluded that the law firm's concurrent representation of CN and Wallace fell squarely within the scope of the bright line rule.

The Canadian National Railway Company retained the law firm to act for it on a variety of matters. In late 2008, the law firm was acting for CN on three ongoing matters. As well, two of its partners held power of attorney from CN for service of process in Saskatchewan. At the same time, the law firm accepted a retainer from Gordon Wallace to act against CN in a $1.75 billion class action based on allegations that CN had illegally overcharged Western Canadian farmers for grain transportation. The Wallace action was legally and factually unrelated to the ongoing CN retainers. The law firm did not advise CN that it intended to accept the Wallace retainer.[2] CN and Wallace were adverse in legal interests. CN had not attempted to tactically abuse the bright line rule; and it was reasonable in the circumstances for CN to expect that the law firm would not concurrently represent a party suing it for $1.75 billion. The law firm failed to obtain CN's consent to the concurrent representation of Wallace, and consequently breached the bright line rule when it accepted the Wallace retainer.[3]

The Supreme Court of Canada observed that the courts have inherent jurisdiction to remove law firms from pending litigation. Disqualification may be required: (1) to avoid the risk of improper use of confidential information; (2) to avoid the risk of impaired representation; and/or (3) to maintain the repute of the administration of justice.[4]

Disqualification is generally the only appropriate remedy where there is a need to prevent misuse of confidential information. Similarly, where the concern is risk of impaired representation, disqualification will normally be required if the law firm continues to concurrently act for both clients. The third purpose that may be served by disqualification is to protect the integrity and repute of the administration of justice. Disqualification may be required to send a message that the disloyal conduct involved in the law firm's breach is not condoned by the courts, thereby protecting public confidence in lawyers and deterring other law firms from similar practices.[5]

On the other hand, the court observed that there is generally no longer a concern of ongoing prejudice to the complaining party where the solicitor client relationship has been terminated and there is no risk of misuse of confidential information. Accordingly, factors that may militate against disqualification must be weighed. These factors may include behaviour disentitling the complaining party from seeking the removal of counsel, such as delay in bringing the motion for disqualification; significant prejudice to the new client's interest in retaining its counsel of choice, and that party's ability to retain new counsel; and the fact that the law firm accepted the conflicting retainer in good faith, reasonably believing that the concurrent representation fell beyond the scope of the bright line rule and applicable law society restrictions.[6]

Some of the factors taken into account by the motions judge in concluding that the appropriate remedy was disqualification were not relevant. Disqualification was not required to prevent the misuse of confidential information. Disqualification was not required to avoid the risk of impaired representation. The only question was whether disqualification was required to maintain public confidence in the justice system. In assessing whether disqualification is required on this ground alone, certain factors may militate against disqualification, and they must be taken into consideration. As the motion judge did not have the benefit of the Supreme Court of Canada's reasons, the matter was remitted to the Queen's Bench for redetermination.[7]
